headline: Trump signs executive order meant to protect the money from Venezuelan oil
summary: President Donald Trump’s new executive order on Venezuelan oil revenue is meant to ensure that the money remains protected from being used in judicial proceedings.  The executive order, made public on Saturday, says that if the funds were to be seized for such use, it could “undermine critical U.S. efforts to ensure economic and political stability in Venezuela.”  The order comes amid caution from top oil company executives that the tumult and instability in Venezuela could make the country less attractive for private investment and rebuilding.

headline: Exxon studies Venezuela return as Chevron plots immediate production bump

headline: Exxon Labels Venezuela 'Uninvestable' Without Major Reforms
summary: President Donald Trump has urged major US oil companies to invest at least $100 billion in Venezuela’s oil sector, a proposition that has been met with skepticism by industry leaders. On Friday, Trump had a meeting with nearly 20 industry representatives in the White House’s East Room. He expressed his anticipation for a swift agreement to rejuvenate operations in Venezuela following the capture of leader Nicolás Maduro. Despite Trump’s positive outlook, several executives voiced their concerns.

headline: ExxonMobil CEO calls Venezuela ‘uninvestable’ without ‘significant changes’
summary: Correction: A previous version of this article incorrectly attributed the comments of Repsol CEO Josu Jon Imaz about company plans for Venezuela to Shell CEO Wael Sawan. Sawan said at the meeting “we have kept boots on the ground in Venezuela all this time, and we now have a few billion dollars’ worth of opportunities to invest in.” - - -Subscribe to The Post Most newsletter for the most important and interesting stories from The Washington Post. headline: Trump seeks to stop courts, creditors from seizing Venezuelan oil revenue in the U.S.
summary: Any use of judicial process against the funds will interfere with efforts to "ensure economic and political stability in Venezuela," the order says.

headline: Trump urges US oil firms to invest heavily in Venezuela
Greenland looks like Trump’s next geopolitical priority. It could also be the oil industry’s next great hope.
summary: Hundreds of miles above the Arctic Circle, an American oil company is attempting to extract billions of barrels of oil on Greenland, just as Trump is escalating tensions with the territory.

summary: In a world where EM are no longer just catch-up stories but laboratories of technological & business model evolution, ex-SOE framework separates engines of progress from machinery of policy.

headline: Trump to Big Oil: Spend $100 Billion in Venezuela. No Government Cash.
summary: President Donald Trump told big oil companies like  Chevron Exxon Mobil  and  ConocoPhillips  that he expects them to spend heavily to rebuild Venezuela’s oil industry, and that they shouldn’t expect financial support from the government.  “The plan is for them to spend—meaning our giant oil companies will be spending at least $100 billion of their money, not the government’s money,” Trump said.

headline: Exxon Calls Venezuela ‘Uninvestable’ as Trump Pushes Oil Plan
summary: Trump convened nearly 20 industry representatives in the East Room of the White House Friday and predicted they could come to an agreement “today or very shortly thereafter” to reinvigorate operations in the oil-rich Latin American country following the brazen capture of leader Nicolás Maduro.  “If you don’t want to go in, just let me know, because I’ve got 25 people that aren’t here today that are willing to take your place,” Trump told the executives.  While many praised Trump and said they relished the opportunity in Venezuela, they stressed that hard work remained before they could make substantive investments.

headline: Trump pushes for $100 billion in oil investments in Venezuela while Exxon and others say it’s currently ‘uninvestable’ without major reforms
summary: Oil giants tell Trump they need stability and considerable legal and political reforms before investing big in Venezuela.
